item.title: 00. Prologue
Dependencies and Maintainers [Drew DeVault]
item.description: Dependencies and Maintainers. Drew DeVault. https://drewdevault.com/2020/02/06/Dependencies-and-maintainers.html. 2020-02-06. Sample Crises in OSS left-pad: trivial library that was removed from npm and was unknowingly present in thousands of dependency graphs. event-stream: maintainer transferred ownership to an unknown individual who added crypto mining heartbleed, in which a bug in a critical security library caused mass upgrades and panic DeVault's Take Asking how to prioritize attention, donations & patches for thousands of OSS library dependencies shouldn't be a problem.

item.title: 01. Firm Foundations and Castles in the Air
item.description: Random walk: future steps or directions cannot be predicted on the basis of past history. Thus, short-run changes in stock prices are unpredictable. Investing as a Way of Life Today Difference between speculations and investments: time period and predictability of the return. To stay even, your returns must match inflation (averaged 4% from 1962 to 2018). With regard to beating inflation, that implies all the money that's in people's bank accounts is depreciating, as opposed to maintaining value.

item.title: 01. A Purposeful Life
item.description: Holmes wanted to be a billionaire since childhood. Her parents were from wealth, with medical and military folk. Holmes attended Houston's most prestigious private school. She spoke her way into Stanford's Mandarin program, while still in high school. Parents insisted on living a purposeful life. Worked in lab during school year. Freshman internship at Genome Institute of Singapore: nasal swabs and syringes. There had to be a better way. Ah, the transformative experience abroad.

item.title: 01. The Tar Pit
item.description: The fiercer the struggle, the more entangling the tar, and no beast is so strong or so skillful but that he ultimately sinks. The Programming Systems Product How do 2 programmers in a remodeled garage build an important program that surpasses the best efforts of large teams? A Program Garage duos typically build a program: complete in itself, ready to be run by the author on the system on which it was developed.

item.title: 02. The Madness of the Crowds
02. The Gluebot
item.description: Holmes insisted on using just a prick of blood. Problem: unreproducible results. A miniaturized catridge made storing and using the reagents hard. You can't Steve Jobs your way through medical devices. But you can't change the world by being cynical. Costs. Each cartridge cost +$200 to make and was single use. Holmes even purchased a $2m automated packaging line. Control of Information. The biochemists and the engineers reported up to Holmes and weren't encouraged to communicate with each other.

item.title: 02. The Mythical Man-Month
item.description: More software projects have gone awry for lack of calendar time than for all other causes combined. Why is this cause of disaster so common? Our estimation techniques assume that all will go well, i.e. each task will take only as long as it “ought” to take. Our estimating techniques fallaciously confuse effort with progress, hiding the assumption that men and months are interchangeable. Because we are uncertain of our estimates, software managers often lack the courteous stubbornness - if you're made to wait, it is to serve you better, and to please you.

item.title: 03. Speculative Bubbles from the Sixties into the Nineties
item.description: The Sanity of Institutions Growth, Tronics and Synergy Growth companies such as IBM and Texas Instruments sold at price-earnings multiples of more than 80. Questioning the propriety of such valuations became almost heretical. Companies plastered “tronics” in their name. The tronics boom came back to earth in 1962. Synergy Generates Energy: The Conglomerate Boom Baker Co. & Electronik Co. have 200k shares outstandings, and $5 earnings per share per year.

item.title: 03. Apple Envy
item.description: Holmes's Grand Plans. The iPod of health care. Build a personal disease map; reverse engineer cancer and predict evolution of tumors. Again, if she's faking this belief, then its sociopathic. But maybe she thought she could do it. Inventors go where no one else dares. They're ridiculed by society. Here's to the crazy ones. The misfits. The rebels. The troublemakers. Chat ports were blocked to protect proprietary information and trade secrets.

item.title: 04. The Explosive Bubbles of the Early 2000s
item.description: Dotcom crash took away $8tn (yearly output of Germany, France, England, Italy, Spain, the Netherlands, and Russia) of market value. The Internet Bubble The internet had 2 bubble qualities: some new technology & some new business opportunity. A Broad-Scale High-Tech Bubble Cisco and JDS Uniphase, producers of the backbone of the Internet, sold at +100 P/E. As usual, companies changed their names to include “dot.com”, “dotnet”, and “Internet”. Stock High ‘00 Low ‘01–‘02 Decline Amazon.

item.title: Agriculture in Kenya as a Portfolio Problem
item.description: Motivation In 08. A New Walking Shoe: Modern Portfolio Theory, Malkiel introduced me to Modern Portfolio Theory, a technique for reducing portfolio risk, despite risky investments. It made me wonder how similar principles are applied in agriculture. This page is the result of that investigation. ~16% of Kenya's land is sufficiently fertile and has good rainfall. In 2006, ~75% of working Kenyans are farmers (compared to 80% in 1980). (en.wikipedia.org)

item.title: 04. Goodbye East Paly
item.description: For some terminated employees, Holmes requested a dossier on them for leverage. Mosley (finance guy) had stored porn on his work laptop. Holmes (retroactively) used that as the cause for his termination and lack of stock options. Matt (IT) wanted to leave to start IT consulting firm. Holmes asking him to use ununionized (mob controlled) movers for a last minute move from East Paly was one of the final straws. Holmes tried asking Matt's peer to build dossier in exchange for Matt's position, but they declined.

item.title: 05. Technical and Fundamental Analysis
item.description: Fundamental analysis applies the firm-foundation theory to the selection of individual stocks. Technical Analysis Study past price movements and trading volume of trading to to predict when to buy/sell a stock. Based on the castle-in-the-air view of stock pricing. What Can Charts Tell You? Principles of Technical Analysis All information about earnings, dividends, and the future performance of a company is automatically reflected in the company’s past market prices.

item.title: 05. The Childhood Neighbor
item.description: Money was a sore point in the Holme's household. Holmes's grandparents had squandered away their share of the Fleischmann fortune. Richard Fuisz, a family friend, was a flashy successful businessman. So in a way, Elizabeth didn't grow up in wealth? This puts a spin on Chapter 01: A Purposeful Life. Fuisz was offended that Elizabeth never consulted him. Fuisz made his money patenting medical inventions that he anticipated other companies would someday want.

item.title: 06. Technical Analysis and the Random Walk Theory
item.description: Is There Momentum in the Stock Market? Past stock prices cannot be used reliably to foretell future movements. Furthermore, transactions costs and taxes make it hard to exploit any short-term momentum. Flip a fair coin many times. Sequences of heads (or tails) and jumbled up sequences occur with equal probability. Just What Exactly is a Random Walk? In a random walk, knowing all prior moves is no help in predicting the next move.

item.title: 06. Sunny
item.description: Elizabeth met Sunny in Stanford's Mandarin program. She was 18, he was 19 years older and married. Elizabeth had struggled and gotten bullied and Sunny helped her out. Sunny was arrogant and demeaning to employees. Sunny was a sucker for #hours clocked in. 8 hours a day showed a lack of dedication. But Elizabeth had utmost confidence in him. That Sunny (COO) and Elizabeth (CEO) were dating wasn't disclosed to the board.

item.title: 07. How Good is Fundamental Analysis? The Efficient Market Hypothesis
item.description: Fundamentalists tout past earnings growth as a most reliable indicator of future growth. But academics have shown that past earnings growth are no help in predicting future growth. Why is the Crystal Ball So Clouded? Many of the influential changes that affect earnings prospects are unpredictable. Creative accounting procedures produce dubious reported earnings, e.g. pro forma earnings, pushing due payments to future years, etc. Analysts may make errors, e.g. over-estimating the market size.

item.title: 07. Dr. J
item.description: FB's private valuation had doubled to $50b in 6 months. ‘Angry Birds’ showed an app could be a business. Low interest rates made hedge funds consider private startups. Walgreens Dr. J - Walgreens Innovation. Theranos tests could boost revenues. Walgreens agrees to prepurchase $50m of cartridges and loan Theranos $25m. Walgreens: we can't risk a scenario where CVS has a deal with them in 6 months and it ends up being real.

item.description: Many academics agree that to beat the market, one needs to assume greater risk - as opposed to trying to predict the market. Defining Risk: The Dispersion of Returns Business Conditions Possibility of Occurrence Expected Return (R) “Normal” economic conditions \(\frac{1}{3}\) 10% Rapid real growth without inflation \(\frac{1}{3}\) 30% Recession with inflation (stagflation) \(\frac{1}{3}\) –10% $$ \mathbb{E}[R] = \frac{1}{3}(.

item.title: 08. The miniLab
item.description: The miniLab, 4S for short, stemmed from the need for a device that could perform more than just one class of tests. Theranos value prop was now minituarization, as opposed to invention. Current blood analyzers used too much blood and did too few tests. Kent, de-facto Chief Architect of the miniLab, had raised $215k on Kickstarter for his bike lights side project. Elizabeth and Sunny wanted the patent to be transferred to Theranos.

item.title: 09. Reaping Reward By Increasing Risk
item.description: The mystical perfect risk measure is still beyond our grasp. That said, here are some common ones: Beta and Systematic Risk Systematic risk of a security arises from the variability of the general stock market. Diversification does not reduce this risk. Unsystematic risk is the remaining variability that is due to a company's particular factors, e.g. a strike. Diversification reduces this risk. There is no reason for extra compensation. Beta is a measure of the systematic risk.

item.title: 09. The Wellness Play
item.description: Safeway was doing poorly. Burd teased with a ‘wellness play’. He expected the clinics’ to recoup the $350m renovation costs. Testing and rewarding employees would reduce Safeway's health care costs. Theranos would courier samples to Palo Alto for testing. Theranos used a lancet on the index finger AND the good old hypodermic needle to the arm. The results could take 2 weeks as opposed to near-instantaneous. Theranos's results tended to be way off, unless they had been outsourced.

item.title: 10. Behavioral Finance
item.description: Behavioralists believe that investors are not rational in present and future valuations of securities. Furthermore, there are substantial barriers to efficient arbitrage (selling overpriced securities short and buying underpriced ones). The Irrational Behavior of Individual Investors Overconfidence Example: in a survey, 94% of male respondents believed that their athleticism was above average. Hindsight bias makes the world seem predictable. Investors might think they can beat the market. The tendency of “growth” stocks to underperform “value” stocks shows how overoptimistic growth forecasts are.

item.title: 10. Who Is LTC Shoemaker?
item.description: Elizabeth had successfully pitched to James Mattis, 4-star General, about deploying Theranos in Afghanistan. General Mattis was known to look out for his troops. Elizabeth's plan around regulation - the real blood analysis would be beamed to California to be done by professionals; only the CLIA compliance for the Palo Alto lab was needed - no FDA. Lt. Col. Shoemaker, responsible for the army's compliance with medical regulations, was openly critical of the Theranos’ workaround.

item.title: 11. New Methods of Portfolio Construction: Smart Beta and Risk Parity
item.description: Smart Beta Using relatively passive-rule based strategies to gain greater than market returns without assuming more risk than investing in a low-cost total stock market index fund. The Sharpe Ratio: (excess return over the risk-free rate) / (risk of the strategy). The risk-free rate is usually the return from a 3-month treasury bill. Higher Sharpe Ratios are better. Smart beta argues that pure indexing (weighting by market cap) is not optimal.

item.title: 11. Lighting a Fuisz
item.description: Elizabeth sued Richard Fuisz claiming he used Joe & John Fuisz to steal confidential information at McDermott Will & Emery, in order to build the rival patent. Note that John thought his father, Richard, was overbearing. David Boies was legendary: antitrust against MSFT, Al Gore on contested 2000 election, overturning ban on gay marriage in CA. He also intimidated opponents with private investigators. There was paranoia that Quest Diagnostics and Laboratory Corporation of America were thirsty for Theranos's blood.

item.title: 12. Ian Gibbons
item.description: Ian's specialty was immunoassays. His contentions: the devices fell short of the lab bench's accuracy; there was little communication between groups; Elizabeth's dishonesty about Theranos’ capbilities. Ian confided in Channing Robertson, who parroted to Elizabeth, who fired Ian. But his colleagues lobbied him back in. He was in a demoted position though. Paul, previous mentee turned manager, was more compromising with the engineers. Ian was dismayed that Elizabeth's name was usually in 1st place on patents despite negligible scientific contribution.

item.title: 13. Chiat\Day
item.description: Chiat\Day was the agency that Apple had used. Therefore, Theranos would too. Patrick (Chiat\Day) was enamored by Elizabeth's mission. The website models featured all demographics. Elizabeth scheduled Wednesday meetings because that's how Apple did it. Stan Fiorito (Chiat\Day) was more circumspect. Sunny's sales targets had measly research. How were they affording $6m/year retainer? Elizabeth claimed Theranos was saving soldiers’ lives in Afghanistan. She wanted bold claims: 800 tests on a drop of blood More accurate than traditional lab testing Tests ready in < 30min Tests approved by the FDA and endorsed by key medical centers.

item.title: 14. Going Live
item.description: Theranos's Lab was divided into two. The upstairs one, CLIA-certified, was full of commercial diagnostic equipment. The downstairs one had Theranos's tech. 2.5 years of the miniLab's development. But it was still a work in progress. In medical device standards, 3 years is a short time. Sycophants were promoted. Many employees were on H1-B, so they needed Theranos's employment. After LTC Shoemaker, Elizabeth scrapped the remote diagnostics. The samples were to be couriered to Palo Alto.

item.title: 15. Unicorn
item.description: Elizabeth used Shultz's connections to get a WSJ Weekend Interview to coincide with the launch. The interview was a friendly setting, with a pro-business & anti-regulation ethos. Theranos was about to launch. Its devices were being used by the military too. Elizabeth offered Don Lucas a discount investment opportunity - $15m at a $6b valuation; 7 years ago, Theranos was valued at $40m. Uber had raised $361m at $3.5b. Spotify raised $250m at $4b.

item.title: 16. The Grandson
17. Fame
item.description: Richard and Joe Fuisz were tired and battered. They had already spent $2m+ on their defense. What if they lost and were made to cover Theranos's legal expenses? Richard agreed to withdraw patent in exchange for Theranos withdrawing its suit. The Fuiszes had lost. But Joe demanded a public apology from Theranos. Roger Parloff, Fortune Magazine's legal correspondent saw the settlement in Litigation Daily. After speaking to Shultz, Perry, Kissinger, Nunn, Mattis and the 2 new directors: Kovacevich (former Wells Fargo CEO) and Frist (former Senate majority leader), came the June 2014 cover story that catapulted Elizabeth to fame: This CEO Is Out for Blood.

item.title: 18. The Hippocratic Oath
item.description: Alan talked Elizabeth and Sunny out of running HIV tests on diluted finger-stick samples - unreliable potassium and cholesterol results were bad enough. Alan was tired of convincing physicians that blood test results were sound and accurate. He chose to resign and asked his name be taken off the lab's CLIA license. Alan got served with an affidavit. How could Alan go against the most fabled SV unicorn? The litigation would bankrupt him.

item.title: 19. The Tip
item.description: Alan retrieved the proficiency testing email chain through a whistleblower law firm. He forwarded the thread to Carreyrou. The thread showed Sunny admonishing Alan & Mark for running proficiency tests on the Edison and admitting that the device had “failed” the test. Elizabeth was copied on most of the emails. Carreyrou tracked Carmen Washington, who had complained about Theranos's blood tests in Walgreens. 3 of her patients had received questionable test results.

item.title: 20. The Ambush
item.description: Charlotte: I doubt if Theranos's ‘box’ is real. Henry [Kissinger] doubts too and he's been saying he wants out. Tyler got served with an affidavit stating that he'd never spoken to any third parties about Theranos and that he'd give names of [ex]employees who he knew had talked to WSJ. George: Tyler isn't a snitch. Finding out who spoke to WSJ is Theranos's problem. Tyler declined to name WSJ's other sources.

item.title: 21. Trade Secrets
item.description: David Boies led the pack. Tyler is a young and unqualified. Many of your sources are disgruntled ex-employees who are equally unreliable. We do not consent to your publication of our trade secrets. [Well, we do not consent to waiving our journalistic privileges]. Delegation acknowledged ownership of commercial blood analyzers, but for comparison purposes only. Of the Siemens ADVIA and special dilution on the ADVIA, the delegation invoked trade secrets. On how many tests the Edison did: trade secret!

item.title: 22. La Mattanza
item.description: The FDA had approved Theranos's finger-stick tests for HSV-1. But to be fair, the herpes test is a qualtitative (yes/no) test. Most tests are quantitative. Arizona was about to pass a law (lobbied for by yours truly) to allow citizens to get blood tested without a doctor's order. Elizabeth had also gotten cozy with the Obama administration. Instead of showing an error message, the miniLab's screen now showed the test's progress slowing to a crawl.

item.title: 23. Damage Control
item.description: Rupert Murdoch led the most recent $430m funding round with $125m. He followed his gut: he'd invested $150k in Uber for it to become $50m. The investment packket forecasted (profit revenue) of ($330m, $1b) in 2015 and ($505m, $2b) in 2016. Furthermore, Theranos had lined up Cox Enterprises, The Waltons, New England Patriots owner, Carlos Slim, controller of Fiat Chrysler. Elizabeth brought up Carreyrou's story to Murdoch, but Murdoch declined to intervene - saying he trusted the paper's editors to handle the matter fairly.

item.title: 24. The Empress Has No Clothes
item.description: [3 weeks before first article] Erika Cheung's email to Gary Yamamoto (CMS) spurred the surprise inspection on Theranos's labs in less than 3 days. They found so many problems and missing documentation that they planned to return. When they returned, WSJ's article was out and there was pressure. CMS released a letter calling Theranos an “immediate jeopardy to patient health and safety”. Theranos claimed to have fixed many of the deficiencies, and that the problems had no bearing on the soundness of its proprietary tech.

item.title: Epilogue
item.description: March 14, 2018: SEC charges Theranos, Homes and Balwani with conducting “an elaborate, years-long fraud”. To resolve SEC's civil charges, Elizabeth was forced to relinquish her voting control, give back a big chunk of stock, pay a $500k penalty and not be an officer/director in a public company for 10 years. Sunny didn't join Theranos until late 2009. Elizabeth had already been misleading pharmaceutical companies for years about the readiness of her tech.

item.title: Facebook to Pay $550 Million to Settle Facial Recognition Suit [The New York Times]
item.description: Facebook to Pay $550 Million to Settle Facial Recognition Suit. Natasha Singer; Mike Isaac. The New York Times. https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/29/technology/facebook-privacy-lawsuit-earnings.html. 2020-01-29. Illinois’ biometric privacy law requires companies to obtain written permission before collecting a person’s biometrics. Residents have the right to sue for up to $5,000 per violation. Facebook's Tag Suggestions harvested facial data without getting written consent nor telling Illinois users for how long the data would be kept.

item.title: How Do People Invest in the US?
item.description: Index Funds and 401(k) Accounts I assume the return is ~5% There are 4 types of retirement accounts, each with tradeoffs (en.wikipedia.org) 401(k), Roth 401(k), Traditional IRA and Roth IRA The return of lazy portfolios (set and forget) is ~6% (compounded) over 15 years as of 2018 (finpage.blog) Notes from /r/investing's FAQ (reddit.com) The FAQ emphasizes reading books I don't see the urgency. It's not as if I'll be picking my own stocks… Maybe it's for me to know when to call bullshit.

item.title: Investing in Capital Markets
item.description: The Stock Market To trade in the NSE, open a CDS account with a CDA (some commercial banks, stockbrokers, investment banks). In 2006, an Automatic Trading System was introduced so that orders are matched automatically and executed by stockbrokers on a first-come first-served basis. Govt bonds have also been added to the ATS. Securities lending, short-selling and same day turnaround trades are not yet permitted. (kestrelcapital.com) I guess that's why quant funds are not a thing in Kenya.

item.description: Third Base. Scott Galloway. No Mercy, No Malice. https://www.profgalloway.com/third-base/. 2019-12-13. I don’t know much about physics but constantly reference Galileo despite knowing little besides the fact that he dared challenge the church. :-) Dunning–Kruger Effect: a cognitive bias in which people assess their cognitive ability as greater than it is. (en.wikipedia.org) Masayoshi Son turned $20m into Alibaba into $100b. But he's mistaking luck in VC for his superior intuition.

item.title: [BBC] Crows Could be the Smartest Animal Other Than Primates
item.description: Crows Could be the Smartest Animal Other Than Primates. BBC. https://www.bbc.com/future/article/20191211-crows-could-be-the-smartest-animal-other-than-primates. 2019-12-11. New Caledonian crows make hooked tools from soft twigs to scoop insects out of holes. Other animals that use tools: chimpanzees, parrots, alligators and crabs. The crows found the desired stems even when they had been disguised with leaves from a different plant species. There are anecdotes of crow intelligence too, e.g. using cars at a crosslight to crush cashews in Japan (more in this HN thread)

item.description: We ran the numbers, and there really is a pipeline problem in eng hiring.. item.title: [SSC] Book Review: All Therapy Books
item.description: Book Review: All Therapy Books. Scott Alexander. Slate Star Codex. https://slatestarcodex.com/2019/11/20/book-review-all-therapy-books/. All psychotherapy books bring up the (controversial) Dodo Bird Verdict – All psychotherapies are about equally good, and the only things that matters are “nonspecific factors” like how much patients like their therapist.

item.title: The New York Times Sells Premium Ads Based on How an Article Makes You Feel [Poynter]
item.description: The New York Times Sells Premium Ads Based on How an Article Makes You Feel. Rick Edmonds. Poynter. https://www.poynter.org/business-work/2019/the-new-york-times-sells-premium-ads-based-on-how-an-article-makes-you-feel/. 2019-04-10. The NYT piloted ad placements based on the emotions certain articles evoke. The average lift to an ad is 40% NYT can charge more for those ads. Will the newsroom be tasked with producing lots of emotional stories? NYT's claims: The newsroom turned out plenty of emotionally charged stories, anyhow.

item.title: Standing Against Hate [Facebook]
item.description: Standing Against Hate. https://about.fb.com/news/2019/03/standing-against-hate/. https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=19503094. 2019-03-27. Main Article We now ban praise, support and representation of white nationalism and separatism on FB and Instagram We didn't ban them before because their broader concepts, e.g. American pride and Basque separatism, are an important part of people's identity. Experts in race relations have confirmed that white nationalism and separatism cannot be meaningfully separated from white supremacy and organized hate groups.

item.title: Open Source Doesn’t Make Money Because It Isn’t Designed To Make Money [Ian Bicking]
item.description: Open Source Doesn’t Make Money Because It Isn’t Designed To Make Money. Ian Bicking. http://www.ianbicking.org/blog/2019/03/open-source-doesnt-make-money-by-design.html. 2019-03-18. A [fallacious] Just World hypothesis: if something has utility, if it helps people, if it’s something the world needs, if it empowers other people, then there should be a revenue opportunity. Classical scratch-your-own-itch open source software is built by programmers for programmers. And it is wildly successful, but it’s selling to people who aren’t willing to pay.

item.title: Counterintuitive Competitive Advantages [Morgan Housel]
item.description: Counterintuitive Competitive Advantages. Morgan Housel. Collaborative Fund. https://www.collaborativefund.com/blog/counterintuitive-competitive-advantages/. 2019-03-13. Growing big antlers requires lots of Ca and Ph, which are rare. Small antlers were required to survive low-food winters, but big antlers were required to impress females to mate. The Irish elk spiraled to extinction. I get the analogy that Housel is trying to paint, but this seems like an oversimplification. Sure, big antlers are sexy, but if small antlers are all that's left on the menu, I don't think female antlers will think “pass”.

item.title: The Trauma Floor: The Secret Lives of FB Moderators in America [The Verge]
item.description: The Trauma Floor: The Secret Lives of FB Moderators in America. Casey Newton. The Verge. https://www.theverge.com/2019/2/25/18229714/cognizant-facebook-content-moderator-interviews-trauma-working-conditions-arizona. 2019-02-25. Moderators in Phoenix will make just $28,800 per year — while the average FB employee has a total compensation of $240,000. Team leaders micro-manage content moderators’ every bathroom break. Two Muslim employees were ordered to stop praying during their 9min/day of allotted “wellness time”. Employees can be fired after making just a handful of errors a week, and those who remain live in fear of former colleagues returning to seek vengeance.

item.title: The Shady Economics of Buy-One-Get-One Free Deals [The Hustle]
item.description: The Shady Economics of Buy-One-Get-One Free Deals. Zachary Crockett. The Hustle. https://thehustle.co/are-buy-one-get-one-free-deals-worth-it/. 2019-02-17. BOGO goods are usually low-demand, non-efficient, lacking in quality and/or close to the expiration date. The BOGO deal is usually a 50% discount off of the manufacturer’s suggested retail price (MSRP). And oftentimes, this price is artificially marked up to begin with. MyPillow offered BOGO deal on their pillows, but really just doubled the price of the first pillow.

item.title: FB Under Pressure to Halt Rise of Anti-Vaccination Groups [The Guardian]
item.description: FB Under Pressure to Halt Rise of Anti-Vaccination Groups. Ed Pilkington, Jessica Glenza. The Guardian. https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2019/feb/12/facebook-anti-vaxxer-vaccination-groups-pressure-misinformation. 2019-02-12. Vitamin C & Orthomolecular Medicine for Optimal Health. Closed Group. 49,000 approved members. Gironda, an admin, sells high-dose Vitamin C in bulk through Revitalize Wellness. The ‘shop now’ button links to her firm. Revitalize Wellness carries a disclaimer saying that its products are “not intended to treat, diagnose, cure or prevent disease”.

item.title: ESG! The Meme [Epsilon Theory]
item.description: Kobayashi Maru. Epsilon Theory. https://www.epsilontheory.com/kobayashi-maru/. 2019-01-29. Environmental, Social and Governance Investing. So general as to be meaningless: marketing BS (thinking ‘holistically’ about ESG risk factors as part of the investment process) to impact investing (providing wholesale financing for community lending initiatives). ESG! The meme is about selling portfolios as virtue signaling devices. It moves the conversation away from fees and performance to values. Don't you want to make a difference?

item.title: Facebook Monetizing Encrypted Messaging by Analyzing Metadata [Twitter]
item.description: Facebook Monetizing Encrypted Messaging by Analyzing Metadata. @SarahJamieLewis. https://twitter.com/SarahJamieLewis/status/1088914192847917056. 2019-01-25. Claim: FB will track relationships and social groups and make that information accessible to law enforcement. FB is a corporation that needs to make money; surveillance makes them money. Contention: Actual privacy and security must protect metadata as well as content. Cwtch by OpenPrivacy aims to minimize metadata exposed by apps used. It's built on Tor. Challenges: message latency, server reliability & discovery, (online) first contact problem for key exchange.

item.title: Why are glasses so expensive? [LA Times]
item.description: Why are glasses so expensive? The eyewear industry prefers to keep that blurry. David Lazurus. LA Times. https://www.latimes.com/business/lazarus/la-fi-lazarus-why-are-eyeglasses-so-expensive-20190122-story.html. 2019-01-22. Column: How badly are we being ripped off on eyewear? Former industry execs tell all. David Lazurus. LA Times. https://www.latimes.com/business/lazarus/la-fi-lazarus-glasses-lenscrafters-luxottica-monopoly-20190305-story.html. 2019-03-05. Luxottica bought everyone. They set whatever prices they please. Luxottica owns and licenses Armani, Brooks Brothers, Burberry, Chanel, Coach, DKNY, Dolce & Gabbana, Michael Kors, Oakley, Oliver Peoples, Persol, Polo Ralph Lauren, Ray-Ban, Tiffany, Valentino, Vogue and Versace.

item.title: [Summary] (Less Wrong) I Want It My Way
item.description: I Want It My Way!. Nick Hayes. Less Wrong. https://www.lesswrong.com/posts/WiDh3ca3C7GgrNXAn/i-want-it-my-way. 4th Jan, 2019. Letting go of how you think things should be lets you see how things are. Consequently, you'll be able to get better results. Wanting it my way: I believe that failure is bad, and that if I fail, then I personally am I failure. So I have those two things conflated. Then anything I do risks failing, especially new things, so I'd better not do the new things, then.

item.title: [Summary] (DHH) You Probably Won't Make it to the Top
item.description: You Probably Won't Make it to the Top. David Heinemeier Hansson (DHH). Signal vs. Noise. https://m.signalvnoise.com/youre-probably-won-t-make-it-to-the-top-8d2146abb790. 22nd Nov, 2018. Fallacy: If you really set your mind to it, you can do it. Get to the very top. Beat out all the others. That’s how I did it. I just wanted it more, worked hard, and eventually all my dreams came true. I won’t say it’s easy, but it’s up to you!

item.title: [Summary] (Housel) Humble Exits
item.description: Humble Exits. Morgan Housel. The Collaborative Fund. https://www.collaborativefund.com/blog/humble-exits/. 24th Oct, 2018. Jack Welch declined $110m for a 10th season of Seinfeld because he was done with the show. He wanted to end the show on the same kind of peak. The show was based on recreating real events from his and Larry David's normal life. They were running out of material because it had been so long since they experienced a normal life.

item.title: [Summary] (Sivan) Innovation Africa & Water Availability
item.description: Innovation Africa & Water Availability. Sivan (InnoAfrica). Talks at The Keller Center. 2018. Bring in Israeli solar panels and drip irrigation. Pump water from the large reservoirs below. Cost $7,000. Adapting to community: 6-8 weeks on committees, bank accounts; mobile charging stations and barbershops using solar panels for sustainability. Can't sell the water, but you can subsidize it with complementary products. Set up remote monitoring with real time stats in order to schedule maintenance.

item.title: How Does a Market Work? [CS Colloquia]
item.description: Objectives: low latency, high throughput & high reliability. The messages are quite brief, e.g. the ITCH protocol uses 32 bytes per message. Trading firm listens to broadcasts on buys, sells, deletes on ITCH broadcasts. Online sorting to identify profitable trades. Matching engine operates on a first-come-first-served basis. Earlier orders with better price get traded first. Markets run at 50 microsecond scales. Single market peaks at 10Gbps. Peaks are correlated, e.g. “Shit!

item.title: How the Chinese Govt Controls the Media [SoECS]
item.description: Seeing government influence through coordination of sensitive coverage, localization of negative news & crowding out other stories on the front page. Structural topic models (LDA + context, e.g. topic prevalence, choice of words) analyze fundamental aspect of the news that can't be changed. Instead of assuming news follows events, investigate!

item.title: Lessons Learned in Tech Policy [SoECS]
item.description: Local governments face severe constraints. Liaising with big tech for employees on sabbaticals could alleviate this. State legislators may have unfounded opinions, but they have the sway, so work with them. Rural-urban differences. Rural folk were more active. Urban folks wrote angry blogs and that was it.

item.title: The Wolf that Tried to Play Nice [SoECS]
item.description: AT&T restricted FaceTime from running on some data plans. Justifications? FaceTime is preloaded, therefore 100% of users have it FaceTime wasn't efficient in network usage. The capacity was asymmetrical, but video chat is symmetrical Interestingly enough, AT&T required Apple to greenlight it, which they did. AT&T worked with top developers to teach network etiquette.

item.title: Computers Can Solve Your Problem. You May Not Like the Answer. [Boston Globe]
item.description: Computers Can Solve Your Problem. You May Not Like the Answer. What happened when Boston Public Schools tried for equity with an algorithm. David Scharfenberg. The Boston Globe. https://apps.bostonglobe.com/ideas/graphics/2018/09/equity-machine/. 2018-09-21. Teens need their sleep: sleep-deprived teens are at increased risk for poor academic performance, binge drinking, and suicide. BPS laid out the algorithm’s four guiding principles: Increase the number of high school students starting school after 8am Decrease the number of elementary school students dismissed after 4pm Accommodate the needs of special education students wherever possible Generate transportation savings that could be reinvested in the schools Officials picked a solution that attempted to balance several goals — student health, cost savings, and parental happiness.

item.title: Why Mathematicians Can't Find the Hay in a Haystack [Quanta Magazine]
item.description: Why Mathematicians Can’t Find the Hay in a Haystack. Kevin Hartnett. https://www.quantamagazine.org/why-mathematicians-cant-find-the-hay-in-a-haystack-20180917/. 2018-09-17. Irrational numbers occupy most of the number line. If you were to pick a number on the number line at random, there is literally a 100% chance that it will be irrational (probabilities with inifinities are spooky). Yet, we almost never encounter irrational numbers for we can't write them down. The shapes we know best - lines, parabolas, circles, spheres - are the needles, for they can be expressed by simple equations.

item.title: [Summary] (Theory, Evolution & Games) Separating Theory from Nonsense via Communication Norms, not Truth
item.description: Separating Theory from Nonsense via Communication Norms, not Truth. Artem Kaznatcheev. Theory, Evolution & Games. https://egtheory.wordpress.com/2018/09/08/theory-norms/. 8th Sept, 2018. Brian Skinner - how to distinguish good theory from crackpottery Both theorists and crackpots share an irrational self-confidence A crackpot relies primarily on positive evidence Thinks hard about a problem, arrives at a theory that feels right, and then publicizes the result. A theorist incorporates negative evidence: Ponders hard about a problem, arrives at a theory that feels right and then proceeds to try to disprove that theory Takes time to understand competing theories and compare them against her own.

item.title: Is the Lean Startup Dead? [Steve Blank]
item.description: Is the Lean Startup Dead?. Steve Blank. https://steveblank.com/2018/09/05/is-the-lean-startup-dead/. 2018-09-05. Katzenberg (Paramount, Disney Studios & DreamWorks) has raised $1.75b for NewTV, a startup banking on consumers wanting a subscription for 10-minute programs on mobile. They renamed to quibi.com/. At least that makes them more searchable on Google. “NewTV” searches lead to newtv.org, a community media center for the residents of Newton, Massachusetts. After the rubble of the dotcom crash, startups and investors needed a lean approach to survive long enough to generate revenue and profits.

item.title: Random Stuff On the Internet (#1)
item.description: (April 2018) An Apology for the Internet Remember ‘Seasons in the Sun’? I thought it was Westlife's but turns out Terry Jacks is the real owner. Combine that melody and some witty criticism of current technological trends and you get Joy of Tech's comic. Cheers to more cat memes in the sun. Also, relevant XKCD! Burrito Time by Dos Toros As much as I advocate for not being glued to the phone, it's hard to hate the brilliant marketing: one notification sent every day at a random time.

item.title: The Trajectory of Great Ideas [Morgan Housel]
item.description: The Trajectory of Great Ideas. Morgan Housel. Collaborative Fund. https://www.collaborativefund.com/blog/ideas/. 2018-08-14. Sears. Blockbuster. Nokia. AOL. You had a great idea. You discovered a beautiful beach to lay on, but other people didn't just follow you and lay down themselves; they built condos and restaurants while you were watching the sunset. Soon your great idea loses its appeal. But you put so much work into the great idea that it's become an inseparable part of your identity.

item.title: Google's Project Dragonfly [The Intercept]
item.description: Google Plans to Launch Censored Search Engine in China, Leaked Documents Reveal [The Intercept]. Ryan Gallagher. The Intercept. https://theintercept.com/2018/08/01/google-china-search-engine-censorship/. 2018-08-01. Project Dragonfly A censored version of Google search that blacklists websites and search terms about human rights, democracy, religion and peaceful protests. China has 750m people; 80% of its internet access is on Android. There's $$$ to be made. Between 2006 and 2010, Google had maintained a censored Google Search, but was heavily criticized.

item.title: The Average Age of a Successful Startup Founder is 45 [Harvard Business]
item.description: The Average Age of a Successful Startup Founder is 45. Harvard Business Review. https://hbr.org/2018/07/research-the-average-age-of-a-successful-startup-founder-is-45. 2018-07-11. There's a variation among industries: software tends to 40, while oil/gas/biotech tends to 47. Even Gates, Jobs, Bezos, Brin & Page had their growth rates peak when they were middle aged. Different definitions of success, e.g. employment growth, sales growth, IPO/acquisition, came to the same conclusion. VCs may not be looking for growth potential.

item.title: Why I Love B2B over B2C [Atrium]
item.description: Why I Love B2B over B2C. Justin Kan. Atrium. https://www.atrium.co/blog/b2b-vs-b2c/. 2018-07-11. B2B customers will actually pay for your product. You have a clear execution path - they'll tell you and pay for features. Companies don't quickly flip flop between products. Consumers are too price sensitive and finicky. B2B customers are rational, and thus understandable. They care about: Does this solution solve my problem? Is it an important enough solution that I will pay for it?

item.title: [Summary] (Morgan Housel) Immeasurably Important
item.description: Immeasurably Important. Morgan Housel. Collaborative Fund. http://www.collaborativefund.com/blog/immeasurably-important/. 5th July, 2018. Filtering out information is an art, not a science, necessitated by the information overload that we live in. Watch out for the tendency to only preserve information that meshes with how we think the world should be. If you think the world is all art, you miss how much stuff is too complicated to think about intuitively. If you think the world is all data, you'll miss how much is too complicated to summarize in a statistic.

item.title: IBM Watson's Health Saga
item.description: Layoffs at Watson Health Reveal IBM’s Problem with AI. Eliza Strickland. IEEE. https://spectrum.ieee.org/the-human-os/robotics/artificial-intelligence/layoffs-at-watson-health-reveal-ibms-problem-with-ai. https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=17393560. 2018-06-25. Jefferies gives IBM Watson a Wall Street reality check. John Mannes. https://techcrunch.com/2017/07/13/jefferies-gives-ibm-watson-a-wall-street-reality-check/. https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=14766793. 2017-07-13. IBM acquired Phytel, Explorys and Truven for their troves of healthcare data and proprietary analytics. From 2010 to 2015, IBM has spent +$15bn and Watson is still not profitable. Marketed abilities: scan literature & patient history to recommend cancer treatment plans, offer preventative medicine & medical imaging.

item.title: U.S. Files Criminal Charges Against Elizabeth Holmes and Ramesh Balwani [WSJ]
item.description: U.S. Files Criminal Charges Against Elizabeth Holmes and Ramesh Balwani. John Carreyrou. The Wall Street Journal. https://www.wsj.com/articles/u-s-files-criminal-charges-against-theranoss-elizabeth-holmes-ramesh-balwani-1529096005. https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=17323485. 2018-06-15. (Ask HN) Holmes has 200 Patents. If tech didn't work, why not noticed?. Hacker News. https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=17328664. 2018-06-18. Theranos Lessons. Morgan Housel. Collaborative Fund's Blog. https://www.collaborativefund.com/blog/theranos-lessons/. 2019-06-19. This CEO is Out for Blood. Roger Parloff. https://www.fortune.com/2014/06/12/theranos-blood-holmes/. https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=7951019. 2014-06-12. Holmes and COO charged with wire fraud.

item.title: The Psychology of Money [Morgan Housel]
item.description: The Psychology of Money. Morgan Housel. The Collaborative Fund. http://www.collaborativefund.com/blog/the-psychology-of-money/. 2018-06-01. Luck and risk are different sides of the same coin. People underestimate the role of luck and risk. There are a billion investors. By sheer chance, we expect a couple of them to be billionaires predominantly off luck. But it's hard to point fingers after the fact. Some people are born into families that encourage education; others are against it.

item.title: [Summary] (Azeria Labs) The Importance of Deep Work & The 30-Hour Method for Learning a New Skill
item.description: The Importance of Deep Work & The 30-Hour Method for Learning a New Skill. Azeria Labs. https://azeria-labs.com/the-importance-of-deep-work-the-30-hour-method-for-learning-a-new-skill/. https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=17163251. 30 Hour Deep Work Tryout: Scan resources and pick the ones that seem most useful (5 hours) Set up the environment and define structured goals (3 hours) Work towards increasingly difficult goals set in step 2 (22 hours) Each session should be about 4 hours. It takes about 20min to get into the flow.

item.title: An Apology for the Internet - How It Went Wrong [Intelligencer]
item.description: An Apology for the Internet - How It Went Wrong. Noah Kulwin. NY Mag. http://nymag.com/intelligencer/2018/04/an-apology-for-the-internet-from-the-people-who-built-it.html. 2018-04-16. Start with hippie good intentions. A generation embracing new technology as a tool to transform the world for good. Can Duruk: You were going to Facebook not to work but to make the world more open and connected. Mix in capitalism on steroids. To save the world, you first need to take it over.

item.title: Cambridge Analytica Uncovered: Secret filming reveals election tricks [Channel 4]
item.description: Cambridge Analytica Uncovered: Secret filming reveals election tricks. Channel 4 News. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mpbeOCKZFfQ. 2018-03-19. Pay people to take surveys but through an app. Mine their profile data, and also crawl their friends. Identify swayable voters and their sensitivities. Craft targeted ads. Play on (unconscious) fears and hopes. Elections are about emotions, not facts. Data science and social media can help us make sense of and manipulate the chaos. An alternative argument: political misinformation is…

item.title: Why Competitive Edges Die [Morgan Housel]
item.description: Why Competitive Edges Die. Morgan Housel. Collaborative Fund. https://www.collaborativefund.com/blog/why-competitive-advantages-die/. 2018-02-08. The Beginner's Mind Being right is the enemy of staying right because it leads you to forget the way the world works. Knowing you have a competitive advantage reduces the incentive to explore other ideas, especially when those ideas conflict with your chosen strategy. The Burden of Being Profitable Nothing to lose is a wonderful thing to have. Having a quarterly dividend to maintain is what happens after you build something great.

item.title: Betting on Things That Never Change [Morgan Housel]
item.description: Betting on Things That Never Change. Morgan Housel. Collaborative Fund. https://www.collaborativefund.com/blog/betting-on-things-that-never-change/. 2017-07-20. Change by itself is hard. Investors have to spot it before it's obvious. Consumers have to change their behaviors to make it viable. These two points repel each other. Sears bet the Internet changed nothing. Beenz bet the Internet changed everything - creating a points-based currency valid only at online merchants. Amazon bet the Internet changed distribution, but rooted its strategy in selection and low prices.

item.title: [The Atlantic] Brainless Slime That Can Learn by Fusing
item.description: Brainless Slime That Can Learn by Fusing. The Atlantic. https://www.theatlantic.com/science/archive/2016/12/the-brainless-slime-that-can-learn-by-fusing/511295/. 2016-12-21. Most people thought that it was impossible for a cell to learn. Maybe brains are not prerequisites for complex and interesting behavior. If one part of the plasmodium touches something attractive, like food, it pulses more quickly and widens. If another part meets something repulsive, like light, it pulses more slowly and shrinks. By adding up all of these effects, the plasmodium flows in the best possible direction without a single conscious thought.

item.title: [Summary] (Syll) What is Ergodicity?
item.description: What is Ergodicity?. Lars P. Syll. https://larspsyll.wordpress.com/2016/11/23/what-is-ergodicity-2/. 23rd Nov, 2016. A random process is ergodic if all of its statistics can be determined from a sample function of the process. That is, the ensemble averages equal the corresponding time averages with probability one. Role of Ergodicity in Human Inference A newspaper has previously printed some inaccurate information, therefore, the newspaper is going to publish inaccurate information in the future.

item.title: The Trade of the Century: When George Soros Broke the British Pound [Priceonomics]
item.description: The Trade of the Century: When George Soros Broke the British Pound. Rohin Dhar. Priceonomics. https://priceonomics.com/the-trade-of-the-century-when-george-soros-broke/. 2016-06-17. Before the EU, Europe had the ERM to fix their exchange rates with the Deutschmark within 6% of the agreed upon rate. Keeping the exchange rate fixed requires governments to nudge the rate, e.g. Use reserves of foreign currency to buy up their own currency Set high interest rates to entice lenders to buy their currency Margaret Thatcher (PM) opposed the fixed exchange rates but lost the vote to Major, an ERM proponent.

item.title: How to Read a Paper [Keshav]
item.description: How to Read a Paper. S. Keshav. David R. Cheriton School of Computer Science, University of Waterloo. https://blizzard.cs.uwaterloo.ca/keshav/home/Papers/data/07/paper-reading.pdf. 2016-02-17. The First Pass (5 - 10 min) Objectives: category, context, validity of assumptions, contributions and quality of writing. Carefully read the title, abstract, and introduction. Read the section and sub-section headings, but ignore everything else Glance at the math to determine the underlying theoretical foundations Read the conclusions. Mentally tick off references that you've already read.

item.title: [Summary] (Paul Graham) Life is Short
item.description: Life is Short. Paul Graham. http://www.paulgraham.com/vb.html. Jan 2016. Some of it is our own fault (e.g. arguing online). Some of it is forced by circumstances that we choose to endure (e.g. unnecessary meetings at work) Choosing a bullshit minimizing path is error-prone. Your priorities change over time. Periodically evaluate where you are. It helps to have measurable aspects of your life.

item.title: So You Want to Reform Democracy [Medium]
item.description: So You Want to Reform Democracy. Joshua Tauberer. https://medium.com/civic-tech-thoughts-from-joshdata/so-you-want-to-reform-democracy-7f3b1ef10597. 2015-11-22. If there was an idea that could ‘fix’ democracy, it would have been thought-up already. If you don't see your idea out there, it’s because it didn’t work the hundreds of other times someone tried it. Let’s tell representatives what their constituents think. Then they HAVE to vote with us! They don’t necessarily want to know what their constituents are thinking.

item.title: [Summary] (Slate Star Codex) No Clarity Around Growth Mindset
item.description: No Clarity Around Growth Mindset. Scott Alexander. Slate Star Codex. https://slatestarcodex.com/2015/04/08/no-clarity-around-growth-mindset-yet/. 8th April, 2015. Growth mindset: people who believe effort - and not ability - determines success are more resilient, skillful, hard-working, perseverant in the face of failure. Most of the growth mindset experiments prime their subjects, but recent priming experiments have famously failed to replicate. Dweck's experiment: Group A: easy test (success) -> final bound-to-fail test Group B: hard test (told they're not working hard enough) -> final bound-to-fail test Group B outperformed Group A.

item.title: [Summary] (Eliezer Yudkowsy) Against Rationalization
item.description: Against Rationalization. Eliezer Yudkowsky. Rationality: From AI to Zombies. Feb 2015. In real life, you have to gather evidence, which may be costly. At some point you have to decide that you have enough evidence to stop and choose. A motivated skeptic asks if the evidence compels them to accept the conclusion; a motivated credulist asks if the evidence allows them to accept the conclusion. Suspect motivated stopping when you close off the search, after coming to a comfortable conclusion, and yet there is a lot of fast cheap evidence you haven't gathered yet.

item.title: [Summary] (Yudkowsky) 0 and 1 Are Not Probabilities
item.description: 0 And 1 Are Not Probabilities. Eliezer Yudkowsky. Rationality: From AI to Zombies. Feb 2015. $$ O = \frac{P}{1 - P},\ \ \ P = \frac{O}{1 + O} $$ When you transform probabilities to odds, 0 goes to 0, but 1 goes to infinity. Now the absolute truth doesn't look like it should be easy to reach. When you transform probabilities to odds, 0.502 and 0.503 goes to 1.

item.title: [Summary] (Yudkowsky) Letting Go
item.description: Letting Go. Eliezer Yudkowsky. Rationality: From AI to Zombies. Feb 2015. Learn when to admit failure It's important to have a watershed moment, the moment of humbling realization. To acknowledge a fundamental problem, not to divide it into palatable bite-size mistakes. Not all mistakes are disguised successes. Don't paint all failures as learning experiences. LTCM were exploiting market inefficiencies. Other people learned of the tricks. LTCM didn't lose hope.

item.title: [Summary] (Yudkowsky) Lotteries
item.description: Lotteries: A Waste of Hope. Eliezer Yudkowsky. Rationality: From AI to Zombies. Feb 2015. New Improved Lottery. Eliezer Yudkowsky. Rationality: From AI to Zombies. Feb 2015. The lottery is a sink of emotional energy. It encourages people to invest in their dreams, their hopes for a better future, into an infinitesimal probability. People can't devalue the emotional force of pleasant anticipation by a factor of .0000001 without dropping the line of reasoning entirely.

item.title: [Summary] (Yudkowsky) The Proper Use of Humility
item.description: The Proper Use of Humility. Eliezer Yudkowsky. Rationality: From AI to Zombies. Feb 2015. To be humble is to take specific actions in anticipation of your own errors. To confess your fallibility and then do nothing about it is not humble; it is boasting of your modesty. Good humility: Engineer humbly designs fail-safe mechanisms into machinery, even though they are damn sure the machinery won't fail. Bad humility: But who can really know whether evolution is correct?

item.title: [Summary] (Yudkowsky) The Third Alternative
item.description: The Third Alternative. Eliezer Yudkowsky. Rationality: From AI to Zombies. Feb 2015. If Santa-belief is destroyed by truth, the children will lose their sense of wonder and stop behaving nicely. It does not follow that Santa-ism is the best of all possible alternatives. People justify questionable policy by pointing to a supposed benefit over the null action. The search for alternatives can go on forever, so one needs a stopping criterion.

item.title: [Summary] (Yudkowsky) There's Still a Chance, Right?
item.description: There's Still a Chance, Right?. Eliezer Yudkowsky. Rationality: From AI to Zombies. Feb 2015. “Humans and chimps have 98% shared DNA.” Maybe the DNA is just similar by coincidence. You say the odds are tiny, but there's still a chance, right? The problem is that probability theory sometimes lets us calculate a chance which is, indeed, too tiny to be worth the mental space to keep track of it - but by that time, you've already calculated it.

item.title: [Summary] (SSC) The Parable of the Talents
item.description: The Parable of the Talents. Scott Alexander. Slate Star Codex. https://slatestarcodex.com/2015/01/31/the-parable-of-the-talents/. 31st Jan, 2015. Overweight people, depressed people, and poor people aren’t fully to blame for their situation – and neither are unintelligent people. It’s accidents of birth all the way down. Srinivasa Ramanujan: Grew up in poverty in a one-room house in small-town India. But a lot of poor people in the US had better conditions/opportunities Either, a lot of intelligence is innate Or, those poor people are just not trying hard enough.

item.title: [Summary] (Heaton, Graham) How to Read and Know
item.description: How to Read. Robert Heaton. https://robertheaton.com/2018/06/25/how-to-read/. https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=17424652. June 25th, 2018. Know. Paul Graham. http://www.paulgraham.com/know.html. Dec 2014. Choose your content. Some books are not worth the effort. Reading and experience train your model of the world. Your mind is like a compiled program for which you've lost the source code. At a different time, re-reading the book will be compiled differently because your world model has probably matured more.

item.title: Do Things That Don't Scale [Paul Graham]
item.description: Do Things That Don't Scale. Paul Graham. http://www.paulgraham.com/ds.html. 2013-07-01. Recruit manually. Don't send links. Set them up on the spot. Ask how big the startup would be if you did the right things, not whether you're currently changing the world. Delight your initial customers. Tim Cook can't send handwritten notes, but you can. If you can solve the problem manually, do so while gradually automating the most pressing bottlenecks.

item.title: How to Get Startup Ideas [Paul Graham]
item.description: How to Get Startup Ideas. Paul Graham. http://www.paulgraham.com/startupideas.html. 2012-11-01. Err on the side of having competitors, but make sure that you have a thesis that everyone else is overlooking, e.g. Google wasn't averse to users leaving google.com ASAP The Startup Idea Matrix, (B2B Edition, B2C Edition) is a good start for knowing who to google. In college, take classes in different areas in lieu of taking entrepreneurship classes.

item.title: How Doctors Die [Zocalo]
item.description: How Doctors Die. Zocalo Public Square. https://www.zocalopublicsquare.org/2011/11/30/how-doctors-die/ideas/nexus/. Doctors tend to be fairly serene when faced with death themselves. They know enough about modern medicine to know its limits. They go gently into that good night - no heroics; no CPR. Sometimes, a family really means ‘do everything’, but often they mean ‘do everything that’s reasonable.’ But they may not know what’s reasonable. People have unrealistic expectations of what doctors can accomplish.

item.title: The Submarine [Paul Graham]
item.description: The Submarine. Paul Graham. http://www.paulgraham.com/submarine.html. 2005-04. Many people rely on social proof to form opinions; therein lies the power of PR. PR firms are not dishonest for they need good reputation with news outlets. But PR firms serve overworked reporters with selective truths. The firms feed the same story to different publications at once. Readers see similar stories in multiple places and assume a new trend has come.

item.title: [Summary] (Paul Graham) The Age of the Essay
item.description: The Age of the Essay. Paul Graham. http://www.paulgraham.com/essay.html. Sept 2004. An essay is something that you write to try and figure out something. By definition, you can't begin with a statement. Expressing ideas helps you form them. Writing something that others might read forces you to think well. Think of the essay as an idea graph. At each node, contrary to Geoffrey's Principle of Least Astonishment for UIs, branch out to the most interesting related idea.

item.title: About c13u
item.description: I'm Chege Gitau. I was born and raised in Kenya. My hobbies include basketball, video games, reading books & blogs and drinking plain milk. I blog because it helps me improve my clarity. It also reminds me that I have something worth saying. I envision my posts taking the form of interesting questions. More often than not, my training as a computer scientist will avail tools to help me answer those questions.
